RESULTS Ectopically expressed HDAC6 inhibits IAV infection. the overexpression of HDAC6 in the cells was confirmed by WB. a noticeable deacetylation of the acetylated -tubulin in HDAC6-overexpressing cells compared to the vector-only control confirmed that ectopically expressed HDAC6 was enzymatically active. the transfection efficiency of A549 cells is shown in Fig. 1D. deacetylase activity plays a role in the antiviral property of HDAC6. tubacin binds to one of the two HDAC6 catalytic domains (a feature unique to HDAC6). tubacin treatment increased the release of infectious virions in the medium. a 3.5-fold increase in the virion release was observed from tubacin-treated cells compared to untreated cells. to further analyze the effect of HDAC6 inhibition on IAV infection, PR8-infected cells were examined by thin-section electron microscopy (EM) IAV enters host cell by receptor-mediated endocytosis, replicates its RNA genome in the nucleus, and assembles its progeny on the plasma membrane (22) for virion assembly, all viral components need to be transported to the plasma membrane. acetylation of microtubules has been shown to promote the vesicular transport. increased intracellular acetylated -tubulin level in IAV-infected cells occurs between 6 and 12 h of infection. acetylated -tubulin level due to HDAC6 depletion and tubacin treatment corresponds with the decrease in intracellular NP level. a basal level of acetylated microtubules was visualized in mock-treated cells. but in tubacin-treated cells, acetylated microtubules mediate the trafficking of viral HA. a single-cell population of PR8-infected cells was prepared, stained for HA. vRNP complex was visualized by staining for vRNP constituents NP and PB2. vRNPs were more or less evenly
